section.description:
This section is comprised of 50 questions and must be completed within 60 minutes.

The Reading Comprehension section of this test contains reading passages that can be viewed on the same page as the question.

The reading passages are longer than the screen, so they are placed in a window. A scroll bar to the right of the passage can be used to scroll down to read the full passage.

question.text: Which of the following statements about antioxidants is NOT true?

option.text: Increasing the gastric pH increases antioxidant absorption.
Preventive antioxidants such as urate reduce the rate of chain initiation.

question.text: Which of the following statements about free radicals is TRUE?

option.text: Most common form of free radicals is the very reactive molecule: hydroxyl radicals.
Free radicals are capable of giving away their outer electrons.
Malnourishment can lead to proliferation of free radicals and oxidative stress.

question.text: Which of the following statements does NOT describe vitamin E?

option.text: Vitamin E oxidative by-product reacts with ascorbic acid to regenerate phenoxy free radical.
Vitamin E reacts with free radicals forming a non-free radical which is excreted in the bile where it forms new tocopherol.
Vitamin E acts as antioxidant in the retina due to its low oxygen concentration.

question.text: Jake, 25 year-old obese male medical student sought consult last week due to increased cholesterol. His doctor prescribed him with cholestyramine. Jake learned from his class that his current medication can interfere with the absorption of the following antioxidants:
Jake takes beta-carotene supplements in doses a bit higher than usual. He is not worried about vitamin A toxicity because:

option.text: Beta-carotene is only active at low oxygen pressures.
Conversion of beta-carotene to vitamin A is decreased when body stores of vitamin A are high.

question.text: After 1 year, Jake lost some weight and his repeat cholesterol exam revealed normal results. He was advised to stop taking cholestyramine and to continue taking in healthy foods. To ensure good absorption of antioxidants, which of the following should NOT be included in his diet?
If Jake wants to reduce his risk of developing prostate cancer in the future, which of the following should be added in his diet?
To normalize the colon function, which antioxidant is advised?
Cancer cells proliferate when:

option.text: There is communication between cells promoting cancer cell growth.
HIF-1 is decreased thereby decreasing available sugar to the cells.
Too many oxygen species are produced due to radiation.
There is too much neurotransmitter dopamine promoting Parkinson's disease.

question.text: To prevent complications in the cardiovascular system, one has to increase intake of which antioxidant?
This chemical protects cerebral neurons:
In Brazil, where wheat and other plant foods like rice are the major sources of diet, the following can be hypothesized:

option.text: The antioxidant present can be selenium and carotenoids.
Antioxidants from wheat can be seen in the muscles.
Antioxidants present in this place can be deficient in other places.

question.text: Which of the following chain-breaking antioxidants act in the aqueous phase?
Which of the following antioxidants should be taken in with water?
Mike, a 34-year old smoker is fond of eating carrots. Which of the following can be hypothesized?

option.text: Mike has increased gene expression for connexins.
Carrots should not be taken in with fats for better absorption.
Mike has decreased risk for cardiovascular diseases and lung cancer.
Mike has increased protection against gallstone formation.

question.text: If Mike is concerned with his eye health, he will add which of the following to his diet:
True about free radicals:

option.text: Being by-products of oxidation, they are not capable of forming new free radicals
Can be brought about by too much x-ray exposure
Can be produced by our bodies anytime

question.text: Which of the following statements about HIV is NOT true?

option.text: Chronic, persistent infection is the hallmark of HIV disease.
HIV can infect any age group even newborns.
Just like other viruses, HIV is cleared from the body and the host develops immunity from subsequent infection.
CD4+ T cell count increases at the start of HIV infection.

question.text: Which of the following statements about HIV is TRUE?

option.text: HIV needs CD4 receptor before entering the host cell.
HIV is a DNA virus whose hallmark is the reverse transcriptase enzyme.
HIV is a unique virus because it rarely kills the host during primary infection.

question.text: CD4+ T cell count:

option.text: >350/uL can present with symptoms of dementia.
May drop to zero during chronic infection instantly leading to death.

question.text: Albert, a 20-year old sexually active male recently sought consult at the school clinic regarding his susceptibility to AIDS. Albert disclosed that he had unprotected sexual activity with both men and women since the age of 15. He now presented with cough and progressive weight loss for the last 2 weeks. During routine physical examination, there were enlarged lymph nodes palpated on Albert's neck. Which of the following statements is true?

option.text: Albert's cough and progressive weight loss are definitely pneumocystis carinii pnenomia.
Albert is categorized under category A.
Albert is not showing any symptoms of AIDS and should therefore not be tested for HIV.

question.text: Albert, afraid of any sexual disease, requested for a test to be done in your laboratory. The first test to be done should be:
Albert further asked the possibility of HIV disease in his case. Which of the following would you tell Albert?

option.text: HIV can infect any age group even in his 20s.
The symptoms of HIV can be seen late in the disease even 10 years after onset of infection.
Recurrent cough may present as symptom of HIV since it can affect almost all organs of the body.

question.text: Albert later on disclosed that his long-time partner recently got pregnant and was found positive for HIV. Which of the following drugs should be used to treat Albert's partner?

option.text: Zalcitabine, in combination with other drugs
Zidovudine, in combination with other drugs

question.text: Which of the following is NOT an opportunistic disease?
The hallmark of HIV acts to:

option.text: Incorporate DNA to the host cell chromosome
Activate the cell infected with HIV
Help DNA bud off from the cell to infect other cells

question.text: Lisa, 40 years old, single, was recently diagnosed with HIV. During history taking, she denied any history of sexual contact from either men or women. However, she admitted that she had several boyfriends in the past and also had some form of intimacy with them particularly torrid kissing, and fondling. No other pertinent information was disclosed during the interview except for a history of operation due to ruptured appendicitis 5 years ago. What could be the possible cause for Lisa's diagnosis?

option.text: Transmission from her mother to her during pregnancy
Very intimate, torrid kissing with exchange of body fluids particularly saliva

question.text: Lisa originally sought consult due to progressive difficulty reading and walking for several months. Lisa also needed to use a cane while walking outside the house prompting her to just stay at home most of the time. At home, she needed to prop one hand on walls or furniture to navigate herself around the house. Lisa was previously an achiever and a teacher and these symptoms alarmed her family prompting consult. Based on the clinical presentation of Lisa, she is currently in what category of HIV infection?
Based on Lisa's cognitive function and motor skills, she is in what stage of AIDS dementia complex?
At this stage, her CD4 count may be:

option.text: <200/uL; Lisa is currently presenting as a case of AIDS
>350/uL; Lisa is just in the early stage of AIDS dementia complex
Between 200 - 350/uL; Lisa is near the end-stage of AIDS
At any level, Lisa is still a case of HIV and diagnosis of AIDS is still unknown.

question.text: During initiation of treatment, multiple drug therapy was proposed using Didanosine, Indinavir and Stavudine. Which of the following adverse drug reactions might be present?

After months of treatment, drug combinations were continuously modified to treat the ongoing infection. Lisa noted numbness and tingling sensation on her lips. There was also noted skin rash on her arms. The possible drugs for these side effects are:

After 2 years of continuous treatment, Lisa and her family went back for confinement. Lisa is now unable to control her urine prompting the use of adult diaper. Lisa is also wheelchair-borne and cannot converse properly most of the time. Lisa had recurrent cough for almost a year now. Upon laboratory testing, Lisa's CD4 count revealed 50/uL. Based on her symptoms, what will you tell Lisa's family?

option.text: Lisa is currently in stage 3 of AIDS dementia complex.
Lisa is now suffering from AIDS.
Lisa's low CD4 count makes it impossible for her to survive even for a year.
Therapy is not useful in this stage of progressive disease.

question.text: Which of the following statements describe deoxyhemoglobin?

option.text: <html>The two αβ dimers interact through hydrogen bonds to constrain the movement of polypeptide chains in deoxyhemoglobin.</html>

question.text: Which type of hemoglobin starts synthesis in the bone marrow at about eighth month of pregnancy and is held together by nonconvalent interactions?

Kevin, a 45-year old male who is suffering from diabetes mellitus came in for annual check-up. He is asking for a blood work-up to test his blood sugar. Which type of hemoglobin would you request for?
Which type of hemoglobin appears about twelve weeks after birth?
Which type of hemoglobin is synthesized in the developing bone marrow composed of 2 gamma chains?
During exercise, the pH of blood is lowered thus enhancing oxygen release from hemoglobin. Which of the following happens due to low pH?

option.text: There is increase in the concentration of protons.
There is a shift to the right in the oxygen-dissociation curve.
The hemoglobin assumes the relaxed form of hemoglobin which has higher oxygen affinity.

question.text: Which of the following is NOT true about hemoglobin?

option.text: The hemoglobin tetramer has two identical dimers whose polypeptide chains are held tightly together primarily by hydrogen bonds.
The binding of oxygen to hemoglobin causes the rupture of some ionic bonds between the dimers.

question.text: Which of the following describes the oxygen-dissociation curve?

option.text: Partial pressure of oxygen is plotted at the y-axis against hemoglobin?s percent saturation with oxygen at the x-axis.
The shape of the curve reflects cooperative binding of oxygen of the three subunits of hemoglobin.
The shape of the curve indicates that the affinity of hemoglobin for the last oxygen bound is greater than its affinity for the first oxygen bound.

question.text: Which of the following describes cooperative binding of oxygen?

option.text: It allows hemoglobin to deliver more oxygen to the tissues in response to relatively small changes in the arterial pressure of oxygen.
The binding of an oxygen molecule at one heme group increases the oxygen affinity of the remaining heme groups in the same hemoglobin molecule.
It reflects the steep upward curve.

question.text: Which of the following does NOT affect the binding of hemoglobin to oxygen?
Which of the following does NOT describe oxygen-dissociation curve?

option.text: <html>An increase in partial pressure of CO<sub>2</sub> causes oxygen release from hemoglobin.</html>
<html>A decrease in pH shifts the curve to the right.</html>
<html>A lower CO<sub>2</sub> concentration results in lower affinity for oxygen.</html>
<html>An increase in pH results in greater affinity for oxygen.</html>

question.text: Hemoglobin has a quaternary structure. Which of the following happens as a result of hemoglobin's structure?

option.text: The binding of oxygen to hemoglobin causes the rupture of some of the ionic bonds between the dimers.
The degree of saturation of the oxygen-binding sites on all hemoglobin molecules vary from zero to 100%.
The two dimers are able to move with respect to each other, being held together primarily by polar bonds.
The two dimers interact through a network of ionic and hydrogen bonds that constrain the movement of polypeptide chains.

question.text: The steep upward shape of the oxygen-dissociation curve indicates what?

option.text: Cooperative binding of oxygen by the four subunits of hemoglobin.
Higher affinity of subsequent oxygen binding to hemoglobin.

question.text: Which of the following shows cooperative binding of oxygen?

option.text: <html>The binding of an oxygen molecule at one heme group decreases the oxygen affinity of the remaining heme groups in the same hemoglobin molecule.</html>
<html>In the lungs, the concentration of oxygen is high and hemoglobin becomes virtually saturated with oxygen.</html>
<html>In the peripheral tissues, deoxyhemoglobin releases much of its oxygen for use in the oxidative metabolism.</html>
<html>It permits oxygen delivery to respond to small changes in CO<sub>2</sub>.</html>

question.text: Which of the following statements describe the Bohr Effect?

option.text: <html>At a lower pH, a smaller pO<sub>2</sub> is required to achieve any given oxygen saturation.</html>
The deoxy form of hemoglobin has a greater affinity for protons than oxyhemoglobin.
Raising the pH results in lower affinity for oxygen.
<html>Release of oxygen from hemoglobin is enhanced when there is lower CO<sub>2</sub>.</html>

question.text: Which of the following statements support the steep upward curve or sigmoid shape of the oxygen-dissociation curve?

option.text: The presence of allosteric effectors affects the binding of oxygen to heme groups at other locations on the molecule causing the sigmoid shape.
It ensures hemoglobin to be virtually saturated with oxygen in the lungs.
The steep upward curve reflects the higher affinity of subsequent oxygen binding to hemoglobin.
<html>The curve permits oxygen delivery to respond to small changes in CO<sub>2</sub>.</html>

question.text: Which type of hemoglobin constitutes about two percent of the total hemoglobin and is composed of two alpha and two delta chains?
